awd_titl_txt: Novel Pathways to CS Research Careers: Broadening Target Populations and Scaling Outreach Programs
awd_abstract_narration:
The Computing Research Association (CRA, on behalf of its Subcommittee on the Status of Women in Computing Research (CRA-W), proposes a project to increase and sustain participation in computer science (CS) research by encouraging members of the underrepresented groups in computing (URGs) to earn advanced degrees in computing and engineering in order to pursue research careers in academia, industry or national laboratories. The project builds on CRA-W's previous successes by reshaping and expanding existing programs, both those done on its own and those done in partnerships with others. 

The proposed work will expand CRA-W's work in three ways:

1. Broader Diversity and Improved Scaffolding for Intersectionality. Many CRA-W programs have already broadened beyond their original focus on women to include minorities and persons with disabilities. With this proposal, CRA-W commits to broadening its program portfolio further to partner with orgranizations focused on support for underpresented minorities and persons with disabilities, and to include other diversity demographics such as veterans and LGBTQ people. To support these more diverse constituencies, CRA-W will adapt its mentoring programs to directly address intersectionality concerns.

2. Support for Multiple and Unique Pathways into a Research Career. In recent years, the notion of career pathway has become insufficient for describing the many rich and unique pathways by which computing professionals navigate their careers. With this effort, CRA-W plans to adapt its mentoring programs to support entry and re-entry to CS from other disciplines and to support moves between industry development or start-ups and graduate school or academia.

3. Implementation at Scale. A fundamental challenge in improving diversity lies in finding enough human and technical infrastructure to support the efforts at scale,  in terms of both program operation and in terms rigorous program evaluation. CRA-W will work to bring its expertise in mentoring to scale, identifying features that are critical to success so that its most successful programs can be adopted throughout the computing research community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Through the Novel Pathways to CS Research Careers: Broadening Target Populations and Scaling Outreach Programs from 2018 to 2023, the Computing Research Association's Committee on Widening Participation (CRA-WP) embarked on an ambitious journey to make the field of computing more inclusive and accessible. Recognizing the critical role of diversity in driving innovation, CRA-WP dedicated itself to opening the doors of computing research and education to a broader audience, with a particular focus on underrepresented groups such as women, minorities, and individuals with disabilities. This mission was predicated on the understanding that the more diverse the contributors to a field, the more innovative and dynamic the outcomes will be.

To achieve this vision, CRA-WP formulated a multifaceted strategy aimed at enhancing the representation and success of these groups within the computing domain. Their approach was both ambitious and comprehensive, targeting individuals at various stages of their academic and professional journeys in computing. Through a carefully curated suite of programs, CRA-WP sought to support and nurture talent from undergraduate education to the pinnacle of professional achievement.

Among these initiatives, the Distributed Research Experiences for Undergraduates (DREU) played a pivotal role in providing students with invaluable research opportunities, sparking an enduring interest in further study and innovation. The Graduate Cohort Workshops (GC-Women and GC-IDEALS) emerged as beacons for graduate students, offering essential mentoring, networking, and professional development to help them navigate and excel in their academic and research careers. Career Mentoring Workshops addressed the unique challenges faced by early- and mid-career researchers, providing insights into establishing successful research programs, securing funding, and balancing professional and personal life. Further amplifying the reach and impact of these programs, CRA-WP's participation in major conferences like the Grace Hopper Celebration and the Tapia Conference enriched the initiatives with additional mentoring and networking opportunities.

The impact of CRA-WP's efforts over this five-year period has been significant. Over 2,500 individuals directly engaged with its programs, benefiting from mentoring, professional development, and research experiences. Participant feedback underscored the transformative nature of these initiatives, highlighting increases in computing research interest, self-efficacy, and a sense of belonging within the computing community. The successful transition to virtual formats during the COVID-19 pandemic showcased CRA-WP's adaptability and commitment to inclusivity, maintaining the integrity and effectiveness of their programs in a challenging global context.

CRA-WP's work has had profound implications beyond individual success stories. By cultivating a more diverse cohort of computing researchers and professionals, the organization has contributed to a more inclusive and vibrant computing field. The establishment of a supportive community where underrepresented individuals can flourish and mentor others has been crucial in broadening participation in computing. Collaborative endeavors with other organizations and active involvement in key conferences have enabled CRA-WP to disseminate best practices and inspire similar initiatives, magnifying their impact across the computing research ecosystem.

The systemic change catalyzed by CRA-WP's initiatives extends beyond facilitating individual growth; it has reshaped the computing research landscape to be more welcoming and supportive of diversity. The strategic focus on mentoring and community-building has fostered a robust support network, creating a sustainable environment where underrepresented individuals can thrive. The incorporation of Social Cognitive Career Theory into CRA-WP's program design has addressed the barriers facing underrepresented groups in computing, enhancing outcome expectations, self-efficacy, and social supports to foster an environment conducive to growth and perseverance.

CRA-WP's commitment to continuous assessment and improvement exemplifies a data-driven approach to diversity and inclusion. Through rigorous evaluation, the organization has gleaned insights into the effectiveness of its strategies, enabling continuous refinement and adjustment to maximize impact. Looking forward, CRA-WP's dedication to expanding and enhancing its programs promises to further extend their reach and efficacy. As the computing field continues to evolve, CRA-WP remains at the forefront of ensuring that this evolution reflects the diverse fabric of society. The legacy of CRA-WP's work from 2018 to 2023 will continue to shape the computing research and education landscape, ensuring it remains dynamic, inclusive, and innovative. The organization's efforts not only benefit participants in the short term but also contribute to the long-term vitality and innovation of the computing research community, making a lasting impact on the field.

 


Last Modified: 02/02/2024
Modified by: Erik C Russell
